Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Factors Contributing to Long-Term Stability in the Maintenance of Linguistic Boundaries

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, which trains a graduate student in the methods of conducting empirical, scientific fieldwork, explores the social and linguistic mechanisms that produce and maintain linguistic distinctiveness between languages that have a long history of contact. In a world that has become increasingly linguistically and culturally complex, it is critical to understand what happens when speakers of different languages or linguistic varieties come into contact; to see whether they influence each other or whether linguistic differences are used to maintain social boundaries. Most research on language contact emphasizes the "mutual influence" aspects of contact, where the linguistic varieties in contact converge and become more like each other. This study, in contrast, considers a case in which linguistic boundaries have been stable for at least half a millennium, and seeks to discover the linguistic and social reasons why such a boundary persists today.

Sandhya Narayanan, under the supervision of Dr. Bruce Mannheim of the University of Michigan, will explore how linguistic and social boundaries are maintained between speakers of different indigenous languages, by tracking how speakers use these languages, how they are able to recognize and evaluate differences among themselves, and what structural mechanisms perpetuate the boundary between them. This research investigates the case of contact between Quechua and Aymara, two Native South American languages spoken predominantly in Peru and Bolivia. These languages have been in intimate contact since before the Spanish conquest, but have maintained their linguistic distinctiveness through today. The research tests the hypothesis that differences in the rhythmic timing structures of the languages both maintain the linguistic boundary and - linked to behavioral features - permit people to identify each other at a distance as speakers of one or the other language. The project employs a range of ethnographic and linguistic anthropological methods of data collection and analysis including social network analysis, participant observation, interviews, linguistic life history surveys, textual analysis, and morphosyntactic and interaction based analysis. Findings from this research will inform the types of linguistic and social processes that come out of situations of contact among indigenous South Americans, and advance our understanding of the relationship between language ideologies and language contact. In addition, there is a strong documentation component to this research, because although both languages are still widely spoken in the Andean region, they are in the midst of precipitous decline, and so are endangered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
General Description:

This project investigated the social and linguistic outcomes of long-term inter-indigenous contact between Quechua and Aymara speakers in the Peruvian altiplano in the areas surrounding Puno and Lake Titicaca. The project specifically investigated the ways in which indigenous Quechua and Aymara speakers manage the history and conditions of contact, and what effects those have on the changes found in the languages, but also changes in linguistc practices, ideologies, and social practices in the region which include changes in kinship practices and the rise of ideologized political parties and indigenous nationalist movements. 

The long history of contact between both languages allowed for various linguistic elements to be borrowed into both languages, and has also shaped the grammatical structure of each language, producing unique varieities of Quechua and Aymara that are specific to that region. This mixing of grammatical elements from each language can be seen in everyday useage by older speakers, and particularly by women who work in the market places in and around the region. However, there is now a growing discourse of ethnolingustic difference and ethnolinguistic nationalism that is fueling ideologies of linguistic difference, ethnic difference, and linguistic purism. All of which are changing the basic ways these languages have been spoken in the past and changing histories of interactions between indigenous language speakers in the region. 

In addition creating projects and institutions that work to separate and purify the languages, children are being encouraged to also learn these languages through these institutions and not at home where parents feel that they are not in a position to teach these languages based on their "un-pure" variety to the next generation. Speakers who were once considered good, such as older women, are also have their linguistic knowledge and experience being devalued. Finally, in relation to the rise of ethnolinguistic politics, Quechua and Aymara speakers are negotiating how their newly formulated linguistic varieties map onto political areas in the region, and what the relationship between those geographic areas should be in those situations.

Intellectual Merit:

This project provides a comprehensive linguistic and athropological investigation of language contact between indigenous groups in the Andes in South America. Previous work on indigenous language contact throughout the Americas focus mostly on the relationshp between an indigenous languages and a settler-colonial European language and social structure. However the breadth of contexts investigated where inter-indigenous contact continues to flourish in a settler-colonial context is limited. This study expands on this subfield, and particularly shows the ways that indigenous speakers respond and shape both their linguitic and social practices in response to the changinging political climate and historical conditions surrounding indigenous language, identity, and the maintenance of indigenous communities in a settler-colonial state. 

This project also shows that ways that indigeous speakers live and carry out these projects within urbanized and globalized settings. Previous approaches and ideas to indigeneity and inter-indigenous contact primarily focus on the types of practices and ideologies but within a rural setting. This project however was based both across rural village and urbanized settings, and shows the ways that indigenous populations today are articulating the nature of their contact and relationships with each other and other indigenous groups given the different ways it can be expressed and different spaces that they inhabit in the world.

Lastly, this project also looks at the role that gender relationships play in situations of inter-indigenous contact, and how those are also recruited into shaping the ways that languages should be spoken and who does and does not get ratified as a proper speaker of an indigenous language. Such san approach to the role that gender plays in mediating the consequences of long-term language contact not only speaks to literature on language change and variation, but also provides insights into the gender based inequalities that shape language maintenance and areal multilingualism in a region.

Broader Impacts:

This studys also provides a comprehensive view on how the conditions of inter-indigenous contact also affects and shapes practices involving language maintenance and revitalization. As there is an increase in awareness over mutlingualism, and language maintenance and preservation or revitalization across communities around the globe, a major area that is left out of those conversations are the spaces on the periphery that have experiences generations of contact and the emergence of unique linguistic varieties and social practices as a result of this contact. Understanding these areas offers a broader view of the challenges that these communities face as they too try and participate in language and cultural revitalization projects and indigenous political movements.
